>[snip]
>
>For computer use we have the "Jerome" font, which was created about
>fifteen months ago. I am excited about this as it gives us the
>opportunity to use the half-letters, which I found such an
>interesting facet of Read's Alphabet in handwriting as they provide
>word shapes that are more distinctive than those written with the
>full letters as in Junior Quikscript.

Dr. Berlin http://user.dtcc.edu/~berlin/ hosts a lot of foreign fonts and
such, and while I was messing around with Arabic, I discovered this great
program that you can download at:

ftp://mesa.dtcc.edu/pub/berlin/fonts/keyman32.zip

Arabic letters change shape depending on their position in a word. The
Keyman program (running on windows 3.11, in my case, I don't know about
other windows versions) changes these letter shapes automatically. It can
also be used to create keyboard drivers for say, French wich allows easy
insertion of cicumflexed, umlauted and accented letters. I simply changes
the letters on the screen based on the just typed character AND the
characters before

BUT, we can also create a keyboard driver for Quikscript, which
automatically converts normal letters to their short forms when possible.
You can even simplify typing for people who don't want to press shift all
the time. I am pretty familiar with the newromaji spelling reform scheme.
Newromaji uses a lot of combined characters, which produce only one sound.
The nicest thing about it is that it limits itself to the 26 roman letters.

examples of combined characters are:

au - nOW
ou - sO
dh - THis
ii - EAt
aa - fAther
oor - Or

Using the keyboard driver which you can easily program with Keyman, any
Newromaji I'm typing will be automatically converted to proper shavian or
quikscript. This takes away a lot of effort required for learning the
keyboard layout.

You can also easily change the keyboard layout, without having to touch the
font.

I am not particularly interested in creating this keyboard driver myself,
but I thought it would be useful suggesting this. Creating the driver will
require you to first learn a small programming language, but a tutorial on
how to create a driver is included (you learn how to create a keyboard which
allows you to type the diacritics on vowels just like how it goes on a
typewriter, type the accent first, then the letter, and then the machine
moves on the the next letter, e.g. you type ^e, you get ê, you type 'e, you
get é).
